description.plain:
Rodarius Marcell Green (born August 27, 1998), better known as Rod Wave, is a platinum-selling recording artist originally from St. Petersburg, Florida.

Following the release of three albums under the Hunger Games series title, Rod rose to national prominence after dropping “Heart on Ice” in 2019. The track, a single for his album PTSD, peaked at number 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 with assistance from TikTok and a viral Genius live performance.

Rod continued to garner critical acclaim with the release of Ghetto Gospel in November of 2019 and Pray 4 Love in April of the following year.

In June of 2020, he survived potentially life-threatening injuries after crashing into a pole at over 100 miles per hour. Recovering from internal brain bleeding, he reflected on his trauma on the track,  “Through the Wire.” Pain, past and present, remains a recurring subject matter in his music.

In 2021, Rod released SoulFly, a 19-track project assisted by the singles “Street Runner” and “Tombstone.”

songs.full_title: Heart On Ice by Rod Wave
songs.title: Heart On Ice

description.plain:
“Heart on Ice” is a single for Rod Wave’s fourth studio album, PTSD. Over a melodic piano beat, produced by SpeakerBangerz, Rod raps about his inability to open up to others, how his past memories still haunt him, and how he is wishing for something better.

The song blew up in part due to Rod performance of the song on Genius' Open Mic session. The video garnered over 17 million views and provided a boost to his career. The remix of the song, featuring Lil Durk, was released on September 27, 2019, as a promotional single for Rod’s fifth album Ghetto Gospel.

songs.title: Tombstone

description.plain:
“Tombstone” is the second promotional single and fifth track off of Rod Wave’s 2021 effort, SoulFly. Rod first previewed the song in an Instagram Live in late 2020 and announced the single over Instagram on the day of release.

Over a harder beat with a guitar backing, Rod Wave raps about his come up, his life growing up, and how the real ones will be there when he leaves.

songs.title: Street Runner

description.plain:
“Street Runner” is the second promotional single and the eighth track off of Rod Wave’s 2021 effort, SoulFly. The song samples “Mixed Signals” by Ruth B..

Over a hard beat with a piano backing, Rod Wave raps about missing his loved one due to spent on the road. He reflects on his past and how he is taking himself higher and higher.

songs.title: Cold December

description.plain:
On “Cold December,” Rod Wave raps about his previous relationships over a soulful trap instrumental that samples Hank William Jr.’s “O.D.’d in Denver”. The track first surfaced as a snippet through Rod’s Instagram story in summer 2021 and was leaked shortly after, being met with a positive reaction by fans.

Despite Rod saying the track would “probably never” drop, it was eventually released following pressure from his label as it finalized his contract with them. During an Instagram live session in January 2022, Rod explained:

I was in a $15 million deal contract that I was trying to close on and they was like, ‘They need that song,’ so that’s the only reason why I dropped that shit. But I wasn’t never gon' drop that shit if you want to be technical.

Hours before the song was officially released, Rod performed the song in its entirety to a crowd in Nashville. He dropped a music video the following day, marking his first release of 2022.

songs.full_title: Girl of My Dreams by Rod Wave
songs.title: Girl of My Dreams

description.plain:
“Girl of My Dreams” is the 12th track off of Rod Wave’s fifth studio album, Pray 4 Love. This song is an emotional ballad in which Rod describes what he sees in his dream girl. The album was hinted at on Instagram, along with four other songs off the album being previous releases.

Debuting at #98 on the Billboard Hot 100 for the week ending on April 25th, 2020, “Girl of My Dreams” has blown up largely in part because of the social platform TikTok. The song was met with viral support after the success of Rod’s May 2019 track, “Heart on Ice.”

On May 3rd, 2020, Rod released an accompanying music video to the song. This followed the release of three other music videos, “Fuck The World,” “The Last Sad Song,” and “The Greatest,” all one week apart.

The record is produced by AceLex. His instrumental conceals a stretched and pitched-up sample of Tula’s 2018 track “Bullet”; it can be heard throughout as a faint background vocal line.

songs.full_title: By Your Side by Rod Wave
songs.title: By Your Side

description.plain:
“By Your Side” is Rod Wave’s return after announcing in one of his tracks, “Gone Till November,” that he would be taking a hiatus. The track is his first release, after the release of his third studio album, SoulFly.

Over on a mellow beat with a piano backing produced by TnTXD and Harto Beats, Rod raps about his current life, updating his fans what he had been doing during his break from music, from him finishing his tour to grinding to getting money.

Prior to the release of the track, Rod teased in his Twitter page on November 10, 2021, that he had something for the fans, teasing his return from his hiatus.

I got sum shit 4 y’all 🔥🔥🔥

The track’s chorus heavily interpolates the track, “Hey There Delilah,” with the chorus having similar lyrics, as well as the track’s title being based on one of the lines: “I’m by your side.”

songs.full_title: Richer by Rod Wave (Ft. Polo G)
songs.title: Richer

description.plain:
On “Richer,” Rod Wave recruits fellow 2020 XXL Freshman Polo G to reminisce on their respective come-ups in the rap game from tough childhoods. Aptly, they focus on the wealth they’ve accumulated compared to their competition.

The guitar-based instrumental was produced by new collaborators Flynn Cranston and PlutoBrazy. The latter also has production credits on another SoulFly track, titled “Pillz & Billz.”

songs.title: Nirvana

description.plain: Rod Wave has heavily denied the accusations that this song is a “suicide note” or a cry for help. Lines such as, “If you’re hearin' this, it’s too late (Late)” and “Sad to say I lost the battle against my mind (Mm-mm)” have made fans worried about the artist’s mental health. In an Instagram live, Rod Wave denied the rumors, “I recorded a fucking song and, um, it was about suicide or whatever. But why the fuck would people take that shit and just say that that was my suicide letter?”  Some have taken to social media to condemn Rod Wave, saying that the song was a desperate attempt for attention. Rod Wave addressed this in his Instagram live as well saying, “You forgot who the fuck I was? I don’t need no attention. Did you not see my tour? Did you not see my album sales? I don’t need no extra attention. I had already deleted my Insta and my Twitter and all that shit because of attention.” Rod Wave continues to claim that this song is about suicide prevention.

songs.title: The Greatest

description.plain: “The Greatest” by Rod Wave is a suitable track for his highest performing album up to this point. The track talks about his ascent from the “pavement” and his former life in the streets. Additionally, it explores the mindset of a young Rod Wave who refused to work a minimum wage job after 12 years of schooling, returning rather to hustling in the streets.

songs.full_title: Cuban Links by Rod Wave (Ft. Kevin Gates)
songs.title: Cuban Links

description.plain:
This single details the struggles faced by Rod Wave and Kevin Gates on their paths to stardom. The title of the track is a reference to Raekwon’s 1995 album Only Built 4 Cuban Linx…, a modern classic widely regarded as a pillar of East coast hip hop.

The chains that Raekwon and Ghostface Killah grew up wearing were of Cuban make, which spurred the notion that Cuban links are the strongest and toughest to break. In this track, Rod Wave and Kevin Gates utilize this metaphor to discuss their own upbringings, and how the adversity they faced has shaped them into who they are today.

annotatable.title: Cuban Links

body.plain:
This single details the struggles faced by Rod Wave and Kevin Gates on their paths to stardom. The title of the track is a reference to Raekwon’s 1995 album Only Built 4 Cuban Linx…, a modern classic widely regarded as a pillar of East coast hip hop.

The chains that Raekwon and Ghostface Killah grew up wearing were of Cuban make, which spurred the notion that Cuban links are the strongest and toughest to break. In this track, Rod Wave and Kevin Gates utilize this metaphor to discuss their own upbringings, and how the adversity they faced has shaped them into who they are today.

songs.full_title: Through the Wire by Rod Wave
songs.title: Through the Wire

description.plain:
On “Through the Wire,” Rod Wave reflects on a car accident, in addition to drug abuse, that almost ended his life. In June of 2020, the artist’s Corvette C8 crashed into a pole at a rate of speed over 100 miles per hour, resulting in severe lacerations and internal brain bleeding. In response to the traumatic occurrence, Wave recounts the accident and discusses his addiction to prescription cough syrup.

The song’s title is a reference to Kanye West’s “Through the Wire,” which was created following a 2002 car crash. The accident left West with a fractured jaw, leading him to record the song with his mouth still wired shut.

songs.title: I Remember

description.plain: “I Remember” by rapper and singer Rod Wave is a reflective track down the troublesome childhood he experienced growing up in the projects. From childhood friendships gone wrong, to getting cheated on in a relationship, Rod reminiscies through the good and the bad times.

This song also touches on his general distrust of people in his life, be it friends or family, probably due to the way he was raised.

songs.title: Time Heals

description.plain:
“Time Heals” is a single from the Deluxe version of Rod Wave’s 2021 album “SoulFly (Deluxe)”.

On the track, Rod details his struggles with communication in relationships, additional resentment he’s experienced, and the perpetual effort to confront the heartlessness of others who stand in the way of his journey to fulfilling his life’s desires.

songs.title: Forever

description.plain: “Forever” depicts a lonely Rod Wave reflecting on his romantic encounters. The song employs a bass guitar beat laced with Jazz notes to create a sorrowful ambiance that allows Rod Wave to convey the entire range of his emotions, as he uses the word “forever” repeatedly in the song’s chorus to demonstrate his inability to deal with the break-up.

songs.title: Calabasas

description.plain:
“Calabasas” is a song by the Florida-based rapper Rod Wave, released on June 7, 2019 as a single from his fourth mixtape PTSD.

It includes the only featured artist of the project, the iconic West Coast rapper Earl Stevens, better known as E-40, who collaborates with his younger colleague in order to bring a message of hope in the future, even though life has provided them with so many disappointing experiences and traumas.

songs.title: Extra

description.plain: “Extra” is a depiction of gang related violence and Rod Wave’s inner feelings. The track was released in 2019, as a part of his album “Ghetto Gospel”.  The song explains how Rod Wave basically gets with his gang and shoots people, as proven by the phrase ‘I got ten on his brain, we gon’ leave a nigga dead", and “late at night we reunite”, reuniting being with his gang.

songs.full_title: Quiet Storm by Rod Wave (Ft. December Joy)
songs.title: Quiet Storm

description.plain: The song “Quiet Storm” is a song about young lovers striving through a long-distance relationship. Though long-distance relationships can be complicated the young lovers try to make it work but it only gets worse as both partners start to overthink, and cheating scandals start to weather the storm.

description.plain: Zkd

body.plain: Zkd

songs.lyrics:
HG2 Intro Lyrics[Verse]
Look, I’m sorry baby
I don’t live that kinda life
I be turnt up every night
I ain’t got room for a wife
But she dangerous and damagin’
But shit, you kinda scandalous so maybe you can handle it
But I live the dream
I ain’t yo’ average teen, I don’t sell sandwiches
It’s Heartbreak Hotel season, I get paid for gamblin’
I got two accountants, that’s for money management and managers to manage what they managing
Hate when people say they get it or they understand
‘Cause truth be told, I don’t think you’ll ever stand a chance
You won’t get it ‘til yo’ closest nigga showin’ animosity
Hoes that you barely know try to fuck ya constantly
Hatin’ niggas say that you won’t blow ‘cause you ain’t special
And everywhere you go somebody gotta be extra
They pull ya to the side and try to give you a lecture
And you don’t wanna hear it but you gotta be respectful
If not, they say yo’ head too big ‘cause you up next
And everywhere you go you rock diamonds ‘round yo’ neck
And niggas smile around ya but don’t wanna see you flex
And you don’t step in clubs unless they cut you a check
And, you don’t like clubbin’ but you damn sure can pack ‘em
You walk through malls every Saturday to get reactions
And hoes that used to turn ya down, they come around with actin’
Askin’ for pictures to put kisses in the caption
And you won’t understand until yo’ private life is public
The world love watchin’ you turn nothin’ into somethin’
The life and path you chose consist of nonstop hustlin’
Hittin’ the road, doin’ shows, and elbow rubbin’
You forced to stay away from yo’ cousins ‘cause they be thuggin’
You love ‘em just like brothers but can’t get in no more trouble
Niggas want you to fail and yo’ family want you to bubble
Waitin’ for you to blow and come get ‘em all out the gutter
You wouldn’t understand ‘til you have to hit that road
You’ll never have the time for the people you love the most
Takin’ chances, tryna ball, Knievel in the post
Evil in certain people is really startin’ to show
And you wouldn’t understand until yo’ job is yo’ career
It’s like yo’ sport
You leave the 12th, won’t be back ‘til the 4th
You live hotel to hotel, resort to resort
You got eight bills a month but only one of ‘em yours
And you couldn’t understand if I paid ya
You wouldn’t understand if I made ya, it’s crazy
Life we live daily is major, now understand
I went from a nobody to the fuckin’ man
Everybody fuckin’ mad ‘cause I got that bag and passed the torch
But ain’t nobody pass the torch when I had first jumped off the porch
Me and Chris Atkins in the Cam’ dreamin’ ‘bout that Porsche
I was down alone in that cell, down with no remorse
Me and Shard sittin’ at that table tryna get it right
Me and pops on that phone and we talkin’ prison life
Me and mama goin’ back and forth, kicked out every night
I was kicked out every night
I know it’s hard to have faith in the greatness in yo’ city
‘Cause nobody has ever really made it in yo’ city
Couple church songs, but nobody’s major in yo’ city
Nobody hit the big stage and skated in yo’ city
Niggas got cocky and then they got lazy in yo’ city
Eventually they critically faded in yo’ city
But this young nigga is comin’ to make changes in yo’ city
Changes in yo’ city
Brrdddttt!You might also likeEmbed
